Fungal infection.Other names: Mycoses,[1] fungal disease,[2] fungal infection[3] ICD-10CM codes: Mycoses B35-B49 [4]
Fungal infection.Risk factors: Immunodeficiency, cancer treatment, large surface area wounds/burns,[8][9] organ transplant,[6] COVID-19,[10] tuberculosis
Fungal infection.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, culture, microscopic examination[6]

Allergy.Symptoms: Red eyes, itchy rash, vomiting, runny nose, shortness of breath, swelling, sneezing, and cough.
Allergy.Types: Hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, anaphylaxis[1]
Allergy.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, skin prick test, blood test[3]
Allergy.Treatment: Avoiding known allergens, medications, allergen immunotherapy[6]
Allergy.Medication: Steroids, antihistamines, epinephrine, mast cell stabilizers, antileukotrienes[6][7][8][9]
Allergy.Education required:
Doctor of Medicine (M.D.)
Doctor of Osteopathic medicine (D.O.)
Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery (M.B.B.S.)
Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery (MBChB)

GERD.Other names: British: Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD);[1] gastric reflux disease, acid reflux disease, reflux, gastroesophageal reflux
GERD.Symptoms: Taste of acid, heartburn, bad breath, chest pain, breathing problems[6]
GERD.Causes: Inadequate closure of the lower esophageal sphincter[6]
GERD.Risk factors: Obesity, pregnancy, smoking, hiatal hernia, taking certain medicines[6]
GERD.Diagnostic method: Gastroscopy, upper GI series, esophageal pH monitoring, esophageal manometry[6]
GERD.Differential diagnosis: Peptic ulcer disease, esophageal cancer, esophageal spasm, angina[8]
GERD.Medication: Antacids, H2 receptor blockers, proton pump inhibitors, prokinetics[6][9]

AIDS.Symptoms: Early: Flu-like illness[4]Later: Large lymph nodes, fever, weight loss[4]
AIDS.Risk factors: Unprotected anal or vaginal sex, having another sexually transmitted infection, needle sharing, medical procedures involving unsterile cutting or piercing, and experiencing needlestick injury[4]
AIDS.Prevention: Safe sex, needle exchange, male circumcision, pre-exposure prophylaxis, post-exposure prophylaxis[4]
AIDS.Prognosis: Near normal life expectancy with treatment[5][6]11 years life expectancy without treatment[7]
AIDS.Frequency: 64.4 million – 113 million total cases[8]1.5 million new cases (2021)[8]38.4 million living with HIV (2021)[8]

Diabetes.Symptoms:
Frequent urination
Increased thirst
Increased hunger
Diabetes.Complications:
Metabolic imbalances
Cardiovascular diseases
Nerve and brain damage
Kidney failure
Gastrointestinal changes[2][3][4][5]
Diabetes.Duration: Remission may occur, but diabetes is often life-long
Diabetes.Types:
Type 1 diabetes
Type 2 diabetes
Gestational diabetes
Diabetes.Risk factors:
Type 1: Family history
Type 2: Obesity, lack of exercise, genetics,[2][6] air pollution[7]

Gastroenteritis.Other names: Gastro, stomach bug, stomach virus, stomach flu, gastric flu, gastrointestinitis
Gastroenteritis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, occasionally stool culture[2]
Gastroenteritis.Differential diagnosis: Inflammatory bowel disease, malabsorption syndrome, lactose intolerance[5]
Gastroenteritis.Prevention: Hand washing, drinking clean water, proper disposal of human waste, breastfeeding[2]
Gastroenteritis.Treatment: Oral rehydration solution (combination of water, salts, and sugar), intravenous fluids[2]

Bronchial Asthma.Symptoms: Recurring episodes of wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, shortness of breath[4]
Bronchial Asthma.Complications: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), sinusitis, obstructive sleep apnea
Bronchial Asthma.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, response to therapy, spirometry[6]

Hypertension.Complications: Coronary artery disease, stroke, heart failure, peripheral arterial disease, vision loss, chronic kidney disease, dementia[2][3][4]
Hypertension.Risk factors: Lack of sleep, excess salt, excess body weight, smoking, alcohol,[1][5] air pollution[7]

Migraine.Symptoms: Headaches, nausea, sensitivity to light, sound, and smell[1][2]
Migraine.Differential diagnosis: Subarachnoid hemorrhage, venous thrombosis, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, brain tumor, tension headache, sinusitis,[6] cluster headache[7]

Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Other names: Cerebral haemorrhage, cerebral hemorrhage, intra-axial hemorrhage, cerebral hematoma, cerebral bleed, brain bleed
Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Symptoms: Headache, one-sided weakness, vomiting, seizures, decreased level of consciousness, neck stiffness, fever[1][2]
Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Causes: Brain trauma, aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations, brain tumors[1]
Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Risk factors: High blood pressure, amyloidosis, alcoholism, low cholesterol, blood thinners, cocaine use[2]
Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Treatment: Blood pressure control, surgery, ventricular drain[1]

Jaundice.Symptoms: Yellowish coloration of skin and sclera, itchiness[2][3]
Jaundice.Risk factors: Pancreatic cancer, Pancreatitis, Liver disease, Certain infections

Malaria.Complications: seizures, coma,[1] organ failure, anemia, cerebral malaria[2]
Malaria.Diagnostic method: Examination of the blood, antigen detection tests[1]
Malaria.Prevention: Mosquito nets, insect repellent, mosquito control, medications[1]

Chicken pox.Symptoms: Small, itchy blisters, headache, loss of appetite, tiredness, fever[1]

Dengue.Symptoms: Fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, rash[1][2]
Dengue.Complications: Bleeding, low levels of blood platelets, dangerously low blood pressure[2]
Dengue.Diagnostic method: Detecting antibodies to the virus or its RNA[2]
Dengue.Differential diagnosis: Malaria, yellow fever, viral hepatitis, leptospirosis[5]
Dengue.Prevention: Dengue fever vaccine, decreasing mosquito exposure[1][6]
Dengue.Treatment: Supportive care, intravenous fluids, blood transfusions[2]

Typhoid.Symptoms:
Fever that starts low and increases daily, possibly reaching as high as 104.9 °F (40.5 °C)
Headache, weakness and fatigue, muscle aches, sweating, dry cough, loss of appetite, weight loss, stomach pain, diarrhea or constipation, rash, swollen stomach (enlarged liver or spleen)
Typhoid.Duration: Usually 7–10 days after antibiotic treatment begins. Longer if there are complications or drug resistance.
Typhoid.Causes: Gastrointestinal infection of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi
Typhoid.Risk factors: Living in or travel to areas where typhoid fever is established, Work as a clinical microbiologist handling Salmonella typhi bacteria, Have close contact with someone who is infected or has recently been infected with typhoid fever, Drink water polluted by sewage that contains Salmonella typhi
Typhoid.Prevention: Preventable by vaccine. Travelers to regions with higher typhoid prevalence are usually encouraged to get a vaccination before travel.
Typhoid.Treatment: Antibiotics, hydration, surgery in extreme cases. Quarantine to avoid exposing others (not commonly done in modern times).
Typhoid.Prognosis:
Likely to recover without complications if proper antibiotics administered and diagnosed early. If infecting strain is multi-drug resistant or extensively drug resistant then prognosis more difficult to determine.
Among untreated acute cases, 10% will shed bacteria for three months after initial onset of symptoms, and 2–5% will become chronic typhoid carriers.[1]

Some carriers are diagnosed by positive tissue specimen. Chronic carriers are by definition asymptomatic.[1]

hepatitis A.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dark urine, jaundice, fever, abdominal pain[1]
hepatitis A.Causes: Eating food or drinking water contaminated with Hepatovirus A infected feces[1]
hepatitis A.Prevention: Hepatitis A vaccine, hand washing, properly cooking food[1][3]

Hepatitis B.Symptoms: None, yellowish skin, tiredness, dark urine, abdominal pain[1]
Hepatitis B.Usual onset: Symptoms may take up to 6 months to appear[1]
Hepatitis B.Causes: Hepatitis B virus spread by some body fluids[1]
Hepatitis B.Risk factors: Intravenous drug use, sexual intercourse, dialysis, living with an infected person[4][5]

Hepatitis C.Complications: Liver failure, liver cancer, esophageal and gastric varices[2]
Hepatitis C.Causes: Hepatitis C virus usually spread by blood-to-blood contact[1][3]
Hepatitis C.Diagnostic method: Blood testing for antibodies or viral RNA[1]

Hepatitis D.Other names: Lábrea's black fever, Lábrea hepatitis, Santa Marta fever

Alcoholic hepatitis.Complications: Cirrhosis, Kidney failure, Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech (hepatic encephalopathy), Ascites, Enlarged veins (varices).[1]
Alcoholic hepatitis.Risk factors: Your sex, Obesity, Genetic factors, Race and ethnicity, Binge drinking.[1]

Tuberculosis.Other names: Phthisis, phthisis pulmonalis, consumption, great white plague
Tuberculosis.Symptoms: Chronic cough, fever, cough with bloody mucus, weight loss[1]
Tuberculosis.Diagnostic method: CXR, culture, tuberculin skin test, QuantiFERON[1]
Tuberculosis.Prevention: Screening those at high risk, treatment of those infected, vaccination with bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG)[3][4][5]

Common Cold.Other names: Cold, acute viral nasopharyngitis, nasopharyngitis, viral rhinitis, rhinopharyngitis, acute coryza, head cold,[1] upper respiratory tract infection (URTI)[2]
Common Cold.Symptoms: Cough, sore throat, runny nose, fever[3][4]
Common Cold.Complications: Usually none, but occasionally otitis media, sinusitis, pneumonia and sepsis can occur[5]
Common Cold.Differential diagnosis: Allergic rhinitis, bronchitis, bronchiolitis,[9] pertussis, sinusitis[5]
Common Cold.Prevention: Hand washing, cough etiquette, social distancing, vitamin C[3][10]

Pneumonia.Symptoms: Cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, fever[1]
Pneumonia.Risk factors: Cystic fibrosis, COPD, sickle cell disease, asthma, diabetes, heart failure, history of smoking,  very young age, older age[5][6][7]
Pneumonia.Differential diagnosis: COPD, asthma, pulmonary edema, pulmonary embolism[9]

Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles).Symptoms: Internal: Painless, bright red rectal bleeding[3]External: Pain and swelling around the anus[4]
Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles).Risk factors: Constipation, diarrhea, sitting on the toilet for long periods, pregnancy[3]
Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles).Treatment: Increased fiber, drinking fluids, NSAIDs, rest, surgery[1][6]

Heart attack.Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, feeling faint, cold sweat, feeling tired; arm, neck, back, jaw, or stomach pain[1][2]
Heart attack.Complications: Heart failure, irregular heartbeat, cardiogenic shock, cardiac arrest[3][4]
Heart attack.Risk factors: High blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, lack of exercise, obesity, high blood cholesterol[5][6]

Varicose veins.Symptoms: None, fullness, pain in the area[2]
Varicose veins.Risk factors: Obesity, not enough exercise, leg trauma, family history, pregnancy[3]

Hypothyroidism.Symptoms: Poor ability to tolerate cold, feeling tired, constipation, weight gain,[3] depression, anxiety, irritability[4]
Hypothyroidism.Complications: During pregnancy can result in cretinism in the baby[5]
Hypothyroidism.Differential diagnosis: Depression, dementia, heart failure, chronic fatigue syndrome[6]

Hyperthyroidism.Symptoms: Irritability, muscle weakness, sleeping problems, fast heartbeat, heat intolerance, diarrhea, enlargement of the thyroid, weight loss[1]
Hyperthyroidism.Causes: Graves' disease, multinodular goiter, toxic adenoma, inflammation of the thyroid, eating too much iodine, too much synthetic thyroid hormone[1][2]
Hyperthyroidism.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and confirmed by blood tests[1]

Hypoglycemia.Other names: Hypoglycaemia, hypoglycæmia, low blood glucose, low blood sugar
Hypoglycemia.Symptoms: Headache, blurred vision, shakiness, dizziness, weakness, tiredness, sweating, clamminess, fast heart rate, pounding heartbeat, nervousness or anxiety, hunger, nausea, pins and needles sensation, difficulty talking, confusion, loss of consciousness, unusual behavior, lightheadedness, pale skin color, seizures, death[1][2][3][4][5]
Hypoglycemia.Causes: Medications (insulin, glinides and sulfonylureas), sepsis, kidney failure, certain tumors, liver disease[1][6]
Hypoglycemia.Diagnostic method: Whipple's triad: Symptoms of hypoglycemia, serum blood glucose level <70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L), and resolution of symptoms when blood glucose returns to normal [2]
Hypoglycemia.Treatment: Eating foods high in simple sugars, dextrose, glucagon[1]
Hypoglycemia.Frequency: In type 1 diabetics, mild hypoglycemia occurs twice per week on average, and severe hypoglycemia occurs one per year.[3]
Hypoglycemia.Deaths: In type 1 diabetics, 6-10% will die of hypoglycemia.[3]

Arthritis.Symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, redness, swelling, decreased range of motion[2][3]
Arthritis.Risk factors: Family history, age, sex trait, previous joint injury, obesity.[7]
Arthritis.Treatment: Resting, applying ice or heat, weight loss, exercise, joint replacement[6]

(vertigo) Paroymsal Positional Vertigo.Symptoms: Feeling of spinning or swaying, vomiting, difficulty walking[1][2]
(vertigo) Paroymsal Positional Vertigo.Causes: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), Ménière's disease, vestibular neuritis, stroke, brain tumors, brain injury, multiple sclerosis, migraine[1][2]

Acne.Symptoms: Blackheads, whiteheads, pimples, oily skin, scarring[1][2]
Acne.Complications: Anxiety, reduced self-esteem, depression, thoughts of suicide[3][4]
Acne.Medication: Azelaic acid, benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, antibiotics, birth control pills, co-cyprindiol, retinoids, isotretinoin[8]

Urinary tract infection.Other names: Acute cystitis, simple cystitis, bladder infection, symptomatic bacteriuria
Urinary tract infection.Symptoms: Pain with urination, frequent urination, feeling the need to urinate despite having an empty bladder[1]
Urinary tract infection.Risk factors: Catheterisation (foley catheter), female anatomy, sexual intercourse, diabetes, obesity, family history[2]
Urinary tract infection.Differential diagnosis: Vulvovaginitis, urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease, interstitial cystitis,[5] kidney stone disease[6]

Psoriasis.Symptoms: Red (purple on darker skin), itchy, scaly patches of skin[3]
Psoriasis.Causes: Genetic disease triggered by environmental factors[3]
Psoriasis.Treatment: Steroid creams, vitamin D3 cream, ultraviolet light, Immunosuppressive drugs such as methotrexate[5]

Impetigo.Causes: Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes which spreads by direct contact
Impetigo.Risk factors: Day care, crowding, poor nutrition, diabetes mellitus, contact sports, breaks in the skin[3][4]
Impetigo.Prevention: Hand washing, avoiding infected people, cleaning injuries[3]
